channel.title: How to make a repeating loop?
channel.description:
ok well the only method i currently know of for making a loop is the for method but how can i make it something like rsps servers where it gets called every so milliseconds? or does it even use a for method for that?
sorry I'm not that familiar with java as if i read the book, i didn't actually read a tutorial or something I've learnt it all from runescape private servers, but try me i'm not expecting some tutorial i just need to see some type of method of doing it.

item.title: How to make a repeating loop?
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

And fyi, what you are wanting to achieve, is actually the post that went almost unnoticed by javacisnotrecognised.

Read full topic
item.source: How to make a repeating loop?

item.title: How to make a repeating loop?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

There are many different types of loops, suitable to different uses.

for(init; condition; action){
}

while(condition){
}

do{

}while(condition)

As for what you want to do, a sleep would probably be fine, but you probably want to do this for the wrong reason, what are you trying to do?

Read full topic
item.source: How to make a repeating loop?

item.title: How to make a repeating loop?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

ScheduledExecutorService idiots
p.s. abraham2119 both use one thread… what is your point? or did you have no point?

edit: why would you use the swing timer in a non-swing environment, lol. regardless, it being executed in the event dispatch thread isn’t a good idea in the event you are running some type of ui on the same vm, because lengthy logic (or any logic, really, to avoid making a habit) in event dispatch thread = bad… hence why they made swingworker

Read full topic
item.source: How to make a repeating loop?

how do you make a non repeating loop?

item.source: How to make a repeating loop?

item.title: How to make a repeating loop?
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:9, topic:325989”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=422401.msg3101206#msg3101206 date=1263717529]

if you are going to use any of the timer classes in the standard api, use the swing timer, not the util one

Why?
[/quote][quote=java.util.Timer]Corresponding to each Timer object is a single background thread that is used to execute all of the timer’s tasks, sequentially. Timer tasks should complete quickly. If a timer task takes excessive time to complete, it “hogs” the timer’s task execution thread. This can, in turn, delay the execution of subsequent tasks, which may “bunch up” and execute in rapid succession when (and if) the offending task finally completes.[/quote]

javax.swing.Timer:

All Timers perform their waiting using a single, shared thread (created by the first Timer object that executes)

Yeah but the swing timer is still going to suffer from the same issues if a task takes a long time to execute (although maybe it won’t execute in rapid succession afterwards to ‘catch up’).[/quote]no, because the tasks are executed on the edt, not on the thread that performs the actual timing

Read full topic
item.source: How to make a repeating loop?

item.title: How to make a repeating loop?
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:7, topic:325989”][quote author=Graham link=topic=422401.msg3101196#msg3101196 date=1263715497]

if you are going to use any of the timer classes in the standard api, use the swing timer, not the util one

Why?
[/quote][quote=java.util.Timer]Corresponding to each Timer object is a single background thread that is used to execute all of the timer’s tasks, sequentially. Timer tasks should complete quickly. If a timer task takes excessive time to complete, it “hogs” the timer’s task execution thread. This can, in turn, delay the execution of subsequent tasks, which may “bunch up” and execute in rapid succession when (and if) the offending task finally completes.[/quote]

javax.swing.Timer:

All Timers perform their waiting using a single, shared thread (created by the first Timer object that executes)[/quote]

Yeah but the swing timer is still going to suffer from the same issues if a task takes a long time to execute (although maybe it won’t execute in rapid succession afterwards to ‘catch up’).

Read full topic

item.title: How to make a repeating loop?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

By the description you gave it appears that even swing.Timer isnt up to the job.

Best option: one thread starting timer actions using a dynamically sized thread pool.

Read full topic
item.source: How to make a repeating loop?

item.title: How to make a repeating loop?
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:6, topic:325989”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=422401.msg3100704#msg3100704 date=1263687043]
if you are going to use any of the timer classes in the standard api, use the swing timer, not the util one
[/quote]

Why?[/quote]

Corresponding to each Timer object is a single background thread that is used to execute all of the timer’s tasks, sequentially. Timer tasks should complete quickly. If a timer task takes excessive time to complete, it “hogs” the timer’s task execution thread. This can, in turn, delay the execution of subsequent tasks, which may “bunch up” and execute in rapid succession when (and if) the offending task finally completes.
All Timers perform their waiting using a single, shared thread (created by the first Timer object that executes)

Read full topic
